annotation.TEXT: And here's my one gripe with this stage: The reuse of the falling Guts Lift. Granted, this jump is a little easier to make than the one in Citadel Basement, but it's still too much of a close call for my tastes.

Aside from the Changkey spam, my other major problem with this level is the scenery. In some sections, it can actually be a bit difficult to determine what's background and what's a solid structure (case in point, the yellow pipes on this screen, which are actually background elements).

In any case, all the fortress stages are made by the judges of the contest. For the most part, I don't really have a problem with these levels (save for one stage in particular, along with one or two design choices in each of the other ones). The opening level is relatively straight forward, as it pretty much should be. With that being said, there's one section here that I really don't care for...

Neon Glass Birdo on a Guts Lift (and yes, that is this thing's official name) is somewhat like the Gravity Man fight, only with way more projectiles. She lobs out stuff associated with Tier 5's levels, which includes several tiny black holes to throw off your shots. If you want a relatively easy way to deal with this fight, just use the Metal Blade (though you'll still have to keep a careful eye on the projectiles).

One other thing I don't like about this level (or rather, just in general): Fake-out boss doors. I understand them being used for mini-bosses and sometimes for aesthetic purposes, but the only thing this leads to is more of the level (despite looking like the lead-up to a boss, corridor and all).

Wily 4 is an interesting case, mainly since it combines gimmicks, enemies, and themes from all of the Tier 5 levels. For the most part however, you won't be seeing much influence from Citadel Basement until the ending stretch. Beyond that, Gravity Man and Glass Man also show up as sub-bosses here as well.

Suddenly, gameplay! To quickly address something: You don't normally just warp to Wily's castle on starting up the game (unless you enter the teleporter first, which is located to the far right of Eddie's shop). I had actually entered into the teleporter beforehand, but had to stop the recording. When I went to record again...well, it just kinda started me up on the Wily stages (so in those regards, I'm sorry for not being able to show the actual entrance to it).

Let's not beat around the bush here: Wily 3 is the worst of the fortress stages (as seems to be per tradition by this point). The gimmick itself is interesting enough: Essentially, killing enemies causes blockades to spawn, complicating the route through the level a bit. The execution however, leaves a lot to be desired. The entire layout of the level is just annoying, especially when it comes to the spike placement and conveyor belts (which feel too unstable for their own good).

If there's one saving grace to this stage, it's that the boss itself is pretty fun. He happens to be weak to Top Spin, though hitting him with it isn't too difficult. It's mostly just a matter of timing and keeping a close eye on his attacks.

As far as this stage goes, I don't have much to say about it (aside from directing my ire at one particular section). Most of it boils down to fighting specific enemy arrangements, with the occasional fan and timed platform section. However, there is at least one new enemy here: The yellow Blockies, whose segments fly towards you when hit. It's a neat adjustment to a pre-existing enemy, but the hitbox for actually triggering them seems pretty wonky.
>tfw you just wish the concept of enemies that jump out of pits would die out already
>GXSCC >Not using Threxx's or even coatlesscarl's actual 8-bit renditions of this song

Let me put this out there: Jumps involving low ceilings (especially when they're covered in or composed of spikes) are not a good idea. Making the platforms timed in some way just makes it even worse. Also, for the record: No, you can't slide along the top three platforms here (the second one will just drop you into the spikes every time).
"Greentext isn't a thing on YouTube, you moron."

The boss of this stage isn't so much a fight as it is an endurance round. The "Shadow Morpher" is completely invincible to your weapons, but it loses a point of health with each transformation. All of its attacks are easy enough to avoid, and it telegraphs which form it'll use next via the screen in the background.

For those of you that have played Bloodborne's DLC: You know how Ludwig makes those weird noises when you talk to him a second time (depending on your garb or your answer to his question)? Those noises are pretty much my reaction to this section right here. Future notice for all fan-game developers: Unless you actively want people to hate your level, never put in timed jumps with low ceilings.
